H0.text: Water is the medium through which light travels more slowly than it does in air.

H1.text: Earth is the medium in which light travels more slowly than in air.

H2.text: Glass is the material in which light travels more slowly than it does in air.

H3.text: Metal is what light travels more quickly in air than.

A4.text: The refractive index of water is approximately 1.3, meaning that light in water travels at c/1.3 ≈ 230,000 km/s, which is slower than in air (c/1.0003 ≈ 299,700 km/s).

A5.text: The refractive index of glass is typically around 1.5, meaning that light in glass travels at c/1.5 ≈ 200,000 km/s, which is slower than in air (c/1.0003 ≈ 299,700 km/s).

A6.text: The refractive index of liquid water (1.333 at 20 °C (68 °F)) is much higher than that of air (1.0)

A7.text: The refractive index of common types of glass ranges from 1.4 to 1.6, which is higher than that of air (1.0)
